title: Detroit Lions' Darius Slay: 'Nobody's safe' after Quandre Diggs trade
text:
CLOSE Detroit Lions cornerback Darius Slay speaks to the media on Thursday, Oct. 24, 2019, in Allen Park. Dave Birkett, Detroit Free Press

Forty-eight hours after they traded one of his best friends to the Seattle Seahawks, Darius Slay is still coming to grips with theDetroit Lions' decision to move on from starting safety and team captain Quandre Diggs.

Slay spoke to reporters for 7 1/2 raw minutes Thursday and shared real emotion about Diggs' departure and the message it sends to the locker room.

"It basically say it don’t matter who you is," Slay said. "No matter how much you put in, at the end of the day it’s a business so that’s how I just look at it. Nobody’s safe, in my opinion."

The Lions traded Diggs and a 2021 seventh-round pick to the Seahawks on Tuesday for a 2020 fifth-round choice.

Diggs, a Pro Bowl alternate last season, was a leader and one of the most beloved players in the Lions' defensive backs room, but the team felt his play had slipped this season.

Slay, who expressed his disappointment with the trade on Twitter immediately after it went down, said he still felt "like (expletive)" Thursday.

"We’ve been playing together five years," Slay said. "Shoot, team captain, so I mean, for that to happen it’s kind of crazy but I guess that’s the business part of it. That was crazy, though."

Slay, who stayed away from the team in a contract dispute this offseason before reporting to training camp without a new deal, said he has not talked to either Lions coach Matt Patricia or general manager Bob Quinn about a move he clearly feels made the team worse in the near-term.

The Lions (2-3-1) hope to use the draft capital acquired from the Diggs trade to bolster their team before next week's trade deadline.

"I ain’t talking to neither one of them about that," Slay said. "That’s they problem. I’m working. That’s all I do. I work. There’s not no kind of relationship or nothing like that, just I’m here, I work here, this is my job. I got to do my job."

Asked if Tuesday's trade gives him pause about his own situation, Slay, who's under contract through the 2020 season, said, "Anybody can get traded but I personally wouldn’t care, my personal feeling. Like I said, it’s a business. I wouldn’t care. It is what it is, go on about the next day."

Asked to clarify, Slay said it's not that he wants out of Detroit.

"Nah, don’t look like that," he said, "I’m just saying the business part of it, they just doing that. That just say that it don’t matter, they’re making choices up there so you just got to live and deal with it."

Slay, a two-time Pro Bowler, aggravated a hamstring injury in last week's loss to the Minnesota Vikings and is not expected to play in Sunday's game against the New York Giants.

He declined to address his health Thursday, and when asked if he had any fears about being moved at next Tuesday's NFL trade deadline Slay said emphatically, "(Expletive) no."

"That’s the last thing I’m worried about," Slay said. "I don’t give a damn, honestly. I don’t. So like I said, I just work. Doesn’t matter where I’m at. If I’m here, if I’m somewhere else. I just go to work.”

Asked if he wanted to remain in Detroit after the deadline, Slay did not offer a direct answer.

"Do I want to? Be where else?" he said. "I’m saying I’m here to play ball. Like I said, it don’t matter if I’m here or not. That’s what I want to do, I just want to play ball."

Slay said he did not view the Lions' business-like approach to shaping the roster as unique in any way. And he said whatever happened with Diggs, it won't impact his play on the field.

"It got nothing to do with on the field," Slay said. "I’m a dog. I just go play ball. That’s not going to affect nothing on the field. It will just affect the relationship in the locker room, the (communication). I probably got to communicate a lot different with folks because me and Quandre have stuff going on, just like I had with GQ (Glover Quinn), how he understood me or how I play, he knew how to play his game from me. Now I just got to build a relationship with other young guys, figure out how we’re going to connect all these pieces together."
description: A two-time Pro Bowler, Darius Slay did not directly answer when asked Thursday whether he wants to stay with the Detroit Lions at the trade deadline
